pullRequest.body:
---

I tried to golf the implementation a bit, I would have expected the following to work:

```lean
complete p := by
  simp
  exact ⟨p.val.length, p.prop.length_lt, p.val, p.prop, rfl⟩
```

... but for some reason only the longer version compiles. Any ideas?

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

### PR summary [1a896fcc4f](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13810/commits/1a896fcc4f8df2f413c88942fadd2ba40e201ddc)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Path.instFintype`
`+ coe_finsetWalkLengthLT_eq`
`+ finsetWalkLengthLT`
`+ fintypeSetPathLengthLT`
`+ fintypeSetWalkLengthLT`
`+ fintypeSubtypePathLength`
`+ fintypeSubtypePathLengthLT`
`+ fintypeSubtypeWalkLengthLT`
`+ mem_finsetWalkLengthLT_iff`
`+ mem_finsetWalkLength_iff`
`- Walk.mem_finsetWalkLength_iff_length_eq`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

I now have a version with `disjiUnion` and `map`. I split up the big definition and introduced definitions for walks with length less than a specific `n`, analogously to the already existing ones for length-`n` walks. The definition for `Path.instFintype` would have gotten very long otherwise.
Can you please merge master?
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
@YaelDillies what should we do about https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13810#discussion_r1723735522 ?
Oh, Henrik must be busy for now. We will update his project once this PR has merged.
And what about mem_finsetWalkLengthLt_iff_length_lt and the implicit arguments?
Oh yes, sorry, I overlooked that. `p` should be implicit. Can you change it?

Just so we are on the same page because I cannot make out a clear answer to the question in my comment: I now changed _my_ definition like you said, but left the existing definition `Walk.mem_finsetWalkLength_iff_length_eq` as before (with `Walk.` namespace and explicit `p`). This means that the definitions are inconsistent with each other, although they are the same statement just for the length-eq and the length-lt cases. If that is not what you meant, please let me know
You should feel free to make `p` implicit in the existing one as well
Since there's still discussion going on, I've removed the `maintainer-merge` label for now.

Okay, I think we're good?

maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
bors merge

I was just reading through this -- happy with the merge, but I personally am not clear about where in the library we're using `Fintype` and where we're using `Finite`. For example in finite group theory we seem to be moving to `Finite`. Why is `Fintype` the preferred option here?

The way I understand it is that with Fintype one can actually compute the elements (because this computation is provided with `elems`) whereas Finite only contains a proof. Since some downstream algorithm may want to enumerate all paths, Fintype seems to be the right choice here. ~~I am lost on when to use Finite vs noncomputable Fintype though~~ the "Finite" docs say to never use noncomputable fintype

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10918375941/job/30303682036)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10918375941/job/30303681649)
maintainer merge
maintainer merge

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion simp? ```

This is going to be inefficient for computation, I think; something like
```suggestion
  elems := (range (Fintype.card V)).disjiUnion
    (fun n ↦ (univ (α := {p : G.Walk u v | p.IsPath ∧ p.length = n})).map
      ⟨fun p ↦ { val := p.val, property := p.prop.left }, sorry⟩) sorry
```
would behave much better.

Of course, this has the downside that you have two proofs to fill!
Sounds good. Out of curiosity, where would this inefficiency show? Is it just that we are avoiding the two extra deduplication steps during construction of the `Finset`?

It would come when evaluating some computable sum over all paths, which would then perform all this deduplication at runtime. It would also appear if you prove something like `example : Fintype.card (G.Path _ _) = 10 := rfl` for some computable `G`.

```suggestion
    simp only [mem_biUnion, mem_range, mem_image, mem_univ, Subtype.exists, true_and]
    exact ⟨p.val.length, p.prop.length_lt, p.val, ⟨⟨p.prop, rfl⟩, rfl⟩⟩
```
Here it complained with just `mem_univ _`: `failed to synthesize Fintype ↑fun p ↦ p.IsPath ∧ p.length < Fintype.card V` - I guess it is fine like this?
I think it's fixed if you do...

```suggestion
      have hl : p.length = l := p.mem_finsetWalkLength_iff_length_eq.mp (hsl hp)
```

```suggestion
      have hl' : p.length = l' := p.mem_finsetWalkLength_iff_length_eq.mp (hsl' hp)
```

```suggestion
    rw [← Finset.mem_coe, coe_finsetWalkLengthLt_eq]
```
@henkkuli, thoughts?

Iffs take implicit arguments
```suggestion
theorem mem_finsetWalkLengthLT {n : ℕ} {u v : V} {p : G.Walk u v} :
```

Ah, I just adapted the lemma from https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/bc3ab3eddef1b92b87d321f25c74899502c25239/Mathlib/Combinatorics/SimpleGraph/Connectivity/WalkCounting.lean#L112 - should we change it there too then?

...this
```suggestion
  elems := (univ (α := { p : G.Walk u v | p.IsPath ∧ p.length < Fintype.card V })).map
```

Yup, that worked! :) 

Any idea why one works better than the other?

`{p : G.Walk u v | p.IsPath ∧ p.length < Fintype.card V}` is a set, `{p : G.Walk u v // p.IsPath ∧ p.length < Fintype.card V}` is a subtype. You were using the latter as a set, which doesn't really work (well, it does, but only if you spend some effort convincing Lean so)

```suggestion
/-- The `Finset` of walks from `u` to `v` with length less than `n`. See `SimpleGraph.finsetWalkLength` for ???. -/
```
where `???` is something you should fill in

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Combinatorics/SimpleGraph): add `Fintype` instance for `Path`
